Turdus merula.description: Familiar garden and park bird, celebrated for its rich, flute-like song at dusk.

Panurus biarmicus.description: Reed-dwelling bird with a long tail; often calls in flocks in wetland reedbeds.

Fringilla montifringilla.description: Winter visitor from the north, often joining mixed finch flocks at feeders.

Anser albifrons.description: Migratory goose with a pale forehead, common on fields and stopover wetlands.

Fulica atra.description: Dark waterbird with a white frontal shield, very common on ponds and lakes.

Cyanistes caeruleus.description: Small, lively tit with blue-and-yellow plumage; a regular visitor to gardens.

Fringilla coelebs.description: Very common songbird with a distinctive call, widespread in forests, parks, and settlements.

Dendrocopos major.description: Characteristic woodpecker of broadleaved forests, often conspicuous by drumming and loud calls.

Corvus monedula.description: Small crow, often in flocks near villages, fields, and open areas.

Garrulus glandarius.description: Striking woodland bird with a harsh alarm call; caches acorns in autumn.

Alcedo atthis.description: Vivid blue-orange fisher that favours clear streams with steep, overhanging banks.

Pica pica.description: Black-and-white crow with a long tail; highly intelligent and adaptable.

Spinus spinus.description: Small finch appearing in winter flocks at alder trees and garden feeders.

Alauda arvensis.description: Open-country bird with a soaring song flight, typical of arable fields and meadows.

Passer montanus.description: Small sparrow with a chestnut cap; common in villages, hedgerows, and field margins.

Columba livia.description: Ancestor of the town pigeon, widespread in settlements and on buildings.

Certhia brachydactyla.description: Inconspicuous climbing bird searching for insects along tree trunks in parks and gardens.

Motacilla cinerea.description: Slender wagtail with a long tail, favouring fast-flowing streams and riverbanks.

Pyrrhula pyrrhula.description: Stocky finch with calm demeanour; male has vivid red underparts, frequents woodland edges.

Emberiza citrinella.description: Yellow-tinged bunting of farmland, singing from fences and hedgerows.

Anser anser.description: Large wild goose and ancestor of most domestic geese, common near water and meadows.

Ardea cinerea.description: Large heron with a long neck, hunting patiently in shallow water and on meadows.

Chloris chloris.description: Robust finch with a nasal call; frequent at feeders, hedgerows, and woodland edges.

Picus viridis.description: Woodpecker of open landscapes, foraging on the ground for ants and giving a loud laughing call.

Lophophanes cristatus.description: Distinctive crested tit found mainly in coniferous forests.

Phoenicurus ochruros.description: Insect-eater of urban areas, often perching on roofs and walls with a scratchy song.

Passer domesticus.description: Classic village bird in gregarious flocks, closely tied to human habitation.

Prunella modularis.description: Unobtrusive songbird of dense undergrowth, with a fine, high-pitched song.

Lullula arborea.description: Rarer lark of dry open areas, with a soft, melodic song flight.

Cygnus olor.description: Large swan with an orange bill and black knob, commonly seen on lakes.

Phasianus colchicus.description: Ground-dwelling gamebird of fields and hedgerows; males are strikingly colourful.

Coccothraustes coccothraustes.description: Powerful finch with a massive bill capable of cracking hard stones and seeds.

Sitta europaea.description: The only native bird that can walk headfirst down a tree trunk.

Parus major.description: Largest native tit; very common, versatile, and vocally diverse.

Corvus corax.description: Largest songbird in Europe, with a deep call and impressive soaring flight.

Phalacrocorax carbo.description: Dark fish-hunter, often seen drying its wings spread-eagled after diving.

Grus grus.description: Migratory bird with a trumpet-like call, often flying in large formations.

Anas crecca.description: Small dabbling duck of shallow water, often gathering in flocks in quiet bays.

Anser brachyrhynchus.description: Arctic goose, seen in central Europe mainly during migration and winter.

Buteo buteo.description: Most common raptor in the region; soars over fields in search of prey.

Turdus viscivorus.description: Large thrush of open woodland, vigorously defending berry-bearing trees in winter.

Corvus cornix.description: Grey-and-black crow, locally common and highly adaptable.

Alopochen aegyptiaca.description: Introduced goose with distinctive eye patches, often seen on park ponds and riversides.

Corvus corone.description: All-black crow, intelligent and common in both farmland and urban settings.

Lanius excubitor.description: Grey shrike observed from elevated perches, hunting from vantage points.
whyNotable: Raptor attitude in a songbird body

Columba palumbus.description: Largest native pigeon with a white neck patch, widespread in forests and towns.

Emberiza schoeniclus.description: Bunting of reedbeds and wet meadows with characteristic calls.

Botaurus stellaris.description: Master of camouflage in reedbeds, often revealed only by its deep booming call.

Turdus iliacus.description: Winter visitor with distinctive rusty-red flanks, often in berry-laden shrubs.

Erithacus rubecula.description: Beloved garden bird with an orange-red breast and clear, liquid song phrases.

Corvus frugilegus.description: Colonial crow with a pale bill base, common on arable farmland.

Tyto alba.description: Pale owl with a heart-shaped facial disc, hunting mainly small rodents.

Mareca strepera.description: Understated dabbling duck of quiet waters; male has finely patterned grey plumage.

Aegithalos caudatus.description: Small, rounded tit with a very long tail; moves in lively, noisy flocks.

Saxicola rubicola.description: Small open-country bird perching on prominent points; male has black head and orange breast.

Dryocopus martius.description: Largest native woodpecker, chiselling conspicuous cavities in old tree trunks.

Cygnus cygnus.description: Northern swan with a yellow-and-black bill, mainly a winter visitor.

Regulus ignicapilla.description: Tiny woodland bird with a vivid crown stripe and very high-pitched calls.

Sturnus vulgaris.description: Gregarious bird with iridescent plumage and a vast vocal repertoire.

Athene noctua.description: Small owl of open landscapes, often linked to traditional orchards and pastures.

Carduelis carduelis.description: Colourful finch with a red face mask and a tinkling call.

Anas platyrhynchos.description: Most common duck on still and slow-flowing waters.

Poecile palustris.description: Unspectacular tit with a clear call, favouring damp deciduous and mixed woodland.

Acanthis flammea.description: Northern finch appearing as a winter visitor in irruption years in alder and birch stands.

Periparus ater.description: Small coniferous-forest tit with a white nape patch and rapid contact calls.

Gallinula chloropus.description: Shy rail relative with a red frontal shield, living in dense waterside vegetation.

Anser serrirostris.description: Passage goose from northern breeding grounds, resting on wet meadows and fields.

Streptopelia decaocto.description: Pale dove with a black collar, a typical resident of human settlements.

Falco tinnunculus.description: Small falcon with a characteristic hovering flight over meadows and roadsides.

Turdus pilaris.description: Thrush of open landscapes, often in large winter flocks.

Certhia familiaris.description: Bark climber of old forests, probing crevices for insects and spiders.

Strix aluco.description: Typical owl of woodland and urban parks, often detected only by its calls.

Asio otus.description: Well-camouflaged owl with prominent ear tufts.

Scolopax rusticola.description: Dense-forest species with a long bill; roding display flight especially conspicuous at dusk.

Tringa ochropus.description: Small wader using pond margins and shallow water on migration and in winter.

Cinclus cinclus.description: Dark mountain-stream bird that dives and walks underwater while foraging.

Rallus aquaticus.description: Very secretive rail of reedbed zones, more often heard than seen.

Poecile montanus.description: Tit of damp woodland, similar to Marsh Tit but with a slightly different call.

Branta leucopsis.description: Contrastingly patterned goose, often at coastal and inland roosts in winter.

Anthus pratensis.description: Open-country bird of damp meadows with a fine song during short song flights.

Regulus regulus.description: Smallest native bird, restlessly searching conifers for tiny insects.

Troglodytes troglodytes.description: Tiny, loud songbird with an upright tail, foraging in dense undergrowth.

Phylloscopus collybita.description: Common leaf warbler named after its call, feeding mainly on small insects.

Haliaeetus albicilla.description: Largest raptor in Germany, often near water or lakes.

Falco peregrinus.description: Fastest bird in a dive, striking prey with complete surprise.

Milvus milvus.description: Raptor with a deeply forked tail, often soaring over farmland.

Milvus migrans.description: Summer visitor, commonly seen near rivers and lakes.

Pandion haliaetus.description: Specialist fish-hunter, hovering over water before plunging feet-first.

Accipiter gentilis.description: Powerful forest hawk, appearing suddenly at feeding stations.

Accipiter nisus.description: Small, agile raptor hunting through hedgerows and gardens.

Circus cyaneus.description: Slender raptor quartering low over fields and heathland.

Circus aeruginosus.description: Reedbed specialist, slowly circling over wetlands.
whyNotable: Easy to watch at breeding sites

Pernis apivorus.description: Secretive raptor that feeds mainly on wasp and bee larvae.

Falco subbuteo.description: Agile small falcon hunting swallows and dragonflies in swift flight.

Bubo bubo.description: Largest owl in Europe, mostly nocturnal and very secretive.

Asio flammeus.description: Diurnal owl that hunts low over open ground.

Ciconia nigra.description: Shy forest stork, considerably rarer than the White Stork.

Ciconia ciconia.description: Well-known cultural companion, often nesting in villages.

Ardea alba.description: Elegant, large heron with pure white plumage.

Platalea leucorodia.description: Distinctive wading bird with a spoon-shaped bill.

Mergus merganser.description: Large sawbill with a shaggy crest, hunting fish in clear rivers.

Mergellus albellus.description: Small sawbill with contrasting plumage, frequent in cold months.

Upupa epops.description: Striking plumage with a prominent crest, calling hoop-hoop.

Merops apiaster.description: Brilliantly colourful insect-hunter, often nesting in colonies.

Oriolus oriolus.description: Yellow-and-black forest bird, more often heard than seen.

Dendrocopos medius.description: Specialised in old broadleaved forests with diverse stand structure.

Picus canus.description: Greenish-grey woodpecker, often in quiet woodland areas.

Picoides tridactylus.description: Rare woodpecker of old coniferous forests and upland zones.

Jynx torquilla.description: Woodpecker relative with an undulating flight and a distinctive call.

Lanius collurio.description: Summer shrike known for impaling prey on thorns as a larder.

Bombycilla garrulus.description: Elegant winter visitor with distinctive red wing-tips.
